stem: A 32-week pregnant client with HELLP syndrome is being monitored. Based on the documentation in the OB-Hepatic Imaging & Symptom Log, which finding is most predictive of a subcapsular hepatic rupture?

options.text: The combination of 'tenting' of the Glisson capsule and profound hypotension.
The presence of right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain.

rationale.correct: This indicates an **impending or active hepatic rupture (a1)**. In HELLP syndrome, the liver capsule (**Glisson capsule**) can become distended by a large hematoma. The 'tenting' or irregular contour on ultrasound (1400) indicates the capsule is about to burst or has already started tearing. Combined with the surgical-level shock (BP 74/42), this is a catastrophic bleed. The shoulder pain (Kehr's sign) occurs because the blood is irritating the diaphragm.
clinicalPearls: The Glisson capsule is the 'skin' of the liver. Stretching it causes extreme RUQ pain.
Hepatic rupture in pregnancy is an ultra-rare but fatal event without immediate surgery.
Treatment involves massive transfusion (MTP) and immediate delivery/laparotomy.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing the fetal decelerations (a4) as the 'predictive' finding.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Late decelerations are a *consequence* of the mother's low blood pressure/bleeding, but they don't 'predict' the cause. The **Glisson capsule status** is the specific anatomical cue for the liver's survival.

mnemonic.title: Pop Goes the Capsule
mnemonic.expansion: Glisson stretches. Pressure drops. Shoulder hurts. Capsule pops.

exhibits.title: SBAR Situation
exhibits.content:
Situation: Progressive right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain.
Background: HELLP diagnosed 12 hours ago. Blood pressure 162/98.
Assessment: Client reports pain 'wrapping around' to the right shoulder blade. Sudden increase in pain intensity from 4/10 to 10/10.
